rows.text_1:
Solving problems together 

Every family faces challenges sometimes. Learning how to solve problems together with your child can help you prevent conflict. 

As children get older, they will be able to work through their problems by themselves more often. 

This will set them up for success throughout their life. What a gift!
rows.media_title: How will it help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

As parents, it can feel like we have to solve a million problems for our children every day: Where is my toy! My brother hit me! I am hungry!

By involving our children in solving problems, they learn to find solutions more and more independently. 

Life has its challenges. If you help your child solve small problems today, you give them the skills to deal with any bigger challenges later in life.

rows.text_1:
We’ll have a look at another family.

{F3_MOTHER} is concerned that {F3_DAUGHTER_7} is sleeping late every day because she starts her homework late. Let’s see how they try to solve the problem together:

rows.text_2:
{F3_MOTHER}: Come on, {F3_DAUGHTER_7}, it's time to get ready for bed.

{F3_DAUGHTER_7}: But I still have so much homework to do!

{F3_MOTHER}: Hm, this is the third night in a row that you haven’t gone to bed on time because of homework.

{F3_MOTHER} : "How can we make sure you get all your work done and still get to bed on time?”

{F3_DAUGHTER_7}: “Maybe I can start earlier?”

 {F3_MOTHER} : “Shall we make a rule that you start your homework half an hour after you get home from school? That way, you can finish it and have some time to relax before bed, too! I am happy to help you a little bit.”

 {F3_DAUGHTER_7} : “Okay, {F3_MOTHER}.”

*The next day.*

 {F3_MOTHER} : “{F3_DAUGHTER_7}, have you started your homework yet?”

 {F3_DAUGHTER_7} : “I'll start now, {F3_MOTHER}! Can I talk to you about this question?”

 {F3_MOTHER} : “Of course, my dear.”

*Later that same day.*

 {F3_DAUGHTER_7} : “Look, {F3_MOTHER}, I'm ready for bed so early tonight!”

 {F3_MOTHER} : “Well done, {F3_DAUGHTER_7}. Thank you for working with me to find a solution that works. Now you can be well-rested for tomorrow!”

rows.text_1:
When something happens, take a deep breath. 

Then help your child work on the problem with these four steps:
rows.section_1_text:
1. KNOW IT 

Put the problem into words.

Talk to your child about what the problem is.
rows.section_2_text:
2. SOLVE IT 
Together, think of possible solutions to this problem.
What could you or your child do differently in this situation in the future?
rows.section_3_text:
3. TRY IT 
Choose one solution together.
Try it next time you are in a similar situation, and praise your child for trying!

rows.text_1:
Identify a problem your child may have and practise the four steps of problem-solving together: Know It, Solve It, Try It, Test It. 

Knowing how to solve problems is something they can use for the rest of their lives!
rows.media_title: How it helped a parent like you:
rows.media_transcript:
I did not have a good relationship with my daughter. I was always shouting at her, and she was refusing to go to school. 

Only when I started spending One-on-One Time with her, I realised that she did not want to go to school because she was being bullied at school. We sat down and used the four steps of problem solving. We identified the problem, and figured out solutions together: “What can I do as a parent so you can attend school and feel safe?”

We agreed I would go talk to the teacher to find a way forward. We really found the solutions together, and we are closer now.
